text.headline: Overview
text.text:
The Lightning Network is a scaling solution for Bitcoin, based on payment channels. While the latter were already conceived by Satoshi Nakamoto, the Lightning Network and its key components arose from the Bitcoin community itself, with many people sharing their thoughts and ideas along the way.

This timeline aims to summarize the corner points of the development of the Lightning Network from the release of its White Paper up to the present state of the network.

text.headline: Discussions about payment channels
text.text:
The ideas about payment channels (a fundamental element of the Lightning Network) are almost as old as Bitcoin itself.

You can read more about the ideas and the people involved in the discussions in this article.

media.caption: Joseph Poon presents the ideas of the paper in March 2015

text.headline: "The Bitcoin Lightning Network" paper released
text.text:
Joseph Poon and Thaddeus Dryja release the paper which later on would often be referred to as the Lightning Network white paper.

While the paper was published as work in progress, the proposed use of Hashed Timelock Contracts for routing payments over multiple channels turned out to be a game-changer.

text.headline: First commit on Blockstreams "c-lightning"
text.text:
After having written a series of blog posts to educate about the ideas behind the Lightning Network, long-time Linux kernel developer Rusty Russell joined Blockstream to start the first implementation of the Lightning Network. It is written in the C programming language and hence called c-lightning.

This event was pivotal not only because the Lightning Network started to move from a concept to reality, but also because this was done by a world-class developer.

Later on he would be joined by Christian Decker, a long-time Bitcoin developer.

text.headline: Most recent version of paper released
text.text: The paper "The Bitcoin Lightning Network" was released in its most recent form, namely the DRAFT Version 0.5.9.2

text.headline: SegWit activates
text.text:
Segregated Witness activated on the Bitcoin blockchain at block 481,824 as a soft fork.

This consensus relevant update was an important acquirement for the Lightning Network, since it solved an issue known as transaction malleability, which was a fundamental precondition for implementing the Lightning Network.

This consensus change had be in the working for a long time and was subject to a lot of controversy, which ended in it being forced upon its enemies in a user activated soft fork.

media.caption: Peter Todd concerned about DoS vulnerability of Lightning Network, one month prior to the attack

text.headline: DDoS Attack
text.text:
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack took down around 200 Lightning Network nodes. At the time this was about 20% of the network, reducing its online nodes count from around 1,050 to 870.

About one month before, cryptographer Peter Todd was warning that the Lightning Network is vulnerable to such an attack in the current state [of that point in time].
